repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

physdesc.extent: 7 record cartons, 3 document boxes, 2 oversized boxes

did.abstract: This collections contains the records of the Africana Center, founded at Tufts University in 1969 to address the needs and concerns of students of African descent. Records include subject files, artifacts, photographs, and publications.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized in four series: Artifacts and posters; Photographs and slides; Publications; and Subject files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of records from the Africana Center. It contains artifacts; photographs; publications; and subject files collected and created by the Africana Center from 1969 to 2012. Materials within the subject files date from 1939-2011. The majority of the collection dates from 1970 â€“ 2005. The material was created or used in the day to day functions of the Africana Center and mainly consists of paper records in the form of subject files.

The artifacts in this collection include banners created by students for Africana Center events, as well as posters, a t-shirt, and buttons and a flag commemorating Martin Luther King, Jr. Photographs in this collection mainly record Africana Center events. Publications and subject files include many formats and cover a wide range of topics, including affirmative action, the Tufts Black Alumni Association, freshmen orientation, student life, Black History month, and guest speakers and performers.

The records relate to the Center's work to enhance the academic mission of the University by ensuring that students of African descent have access to resources supporting a successful Tufts experience and preparing them for leadership positions. The collection covers the Center's work from its founding in 1969 through to its development into a provider of academic and social resources and activities for students of African descent. Some of the larger projects represented in the records include the founding of the Tufts Black Alumni Association; the organization of the freshmen orientation Cape Cod retreat; the development of the Black Student Handbook; the development of the peer advisor program; Black History month events; and the administration of Capen House, a living and learning space for fifteen undergraduates interested in African diaspora history and culture who reside in the house, which is located on the second and third floors of the Africana Center building.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Founded in 1969, the Africana Center was developed in recognition of the realities of the needs and concerns of the students of African descent on a predominately white campus. The Center works to enhance the academic mission of the university by ensuring that students of African descent have access to a variety of academic, cultural and student resources that encourages them to have a successful Tufts experience and prepares them to be leaders for a wide range of professional experiences. In addition, the Center works to ensure that students have access to all necessary resources, advises the administrative and academic offices of the university on such issues and advocates proactively for students. The Africana Center is located at 8 Professors Row on the 1st Floor. The second and third floors of the building serve as a living and learning space (Capen House) for fifteen undergraduates who reside in the house during the academic year. These students are selected each year to live in the dorm and work as a community to complete individual and group projects which celebrate the rich cultural heritage of people of African descent.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection contains some restricted material. Restrictions related to specific material are listed in the detailed contents list.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. Copyright to all materials created by Tufts University employees in the course of their work is held by the Trustees of Tufts University.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Africana Center Records, 1939 -- 2012. Tufts University. Digital Collections and Archives. Medford, MA.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Archives and Research Assistant Rose Koven under the supervision of Collections Management Archivist Adrienne Pruitt in 2018. Materials were placed in archival folders if original folders were damaged, and loose materials were placed in folders where needed. Original folder titles were maintained where applicable, and new titles were assigned where necessary. Folders were received in order grouped loosely by material type and subject. These groupings were largely maintained, although alphabetization was standardized to improve access. Blank forms and empty unlabeled folders were deaccessioned.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Duplicative copies of the publication Onyx were transferred to UP034.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series is open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arrangement reflects the physical order of items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains banners, posters, buttons, flags, and a t-shirt, all created and collected by the Africana Center. The banners and posters document events sponsored by the Africana Center in the 1980s and 1990s. There is also a digitized banner for the 30th anniversary of the Africana Center in 1999. The buttons and flags were created for Martin Luther King Jr. remembrance events.

did.unittitle: Martin Luther King Jr. Scholarship Fund flags
Tufts Remembers Dr. Martin Luther King buttons
Black History Month at Tufts poster

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series contains some restricted material. Restrictions related to specific material are listed in the detailed contents list.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically by folder title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs, slides, and negatives created and compiled by the Africana Center circa 1970 to circa 2005. The subjects of the photographs include events, student life, and a few portraits of visiting speakers such as Sonia Sanchez and Manning Marable. Some events featured in the collection are the pre-freshman orientation at Cape Cod, graduation, award ceremonies, Kwanzaa dinners, fashion shows, sports events, and music and dance performances.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically by folder title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contain publications created or collected by the African Center, including periodicals, newsletters, pamphlets, and handbooks published by the Center, by student groups at Tufts, and by Tufts University. There are also professional association newsletters and periodicals. Subjects covered by the publications vary widely and include affirmative action, Black History Month, African American art, and minority student life.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically by folder title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains subject files compiled by the Africana Center and encompassing many formats, including administrative documents and office files that include financial, personnel, and event documentation; clippings; photographs; correspondence; memos; mailing lists; and reports. Topics of particular note in the subject files include affirmative action; the Black Alumni Association; Black History Month; Capen House, a living and learning space for undergraduates interested in African diaspora history and culture; and student orientation and peer advising.
